     115                 :            : static const unsigned int MAX_HEADERS_RESULTS = 2000;

     120                 :            : static const int MAX_BLOCKTXN_DEPTH = 10;

     122                 :            :  *  Larger windows tolerate larger download speed differences between peer, but increase the potential
     123                 :            :  *  degree of disordering of blocks on disk (which make reindexing and pruning harder). We'll probably
     124                 :            :  *  want to make this a per-peer adaptive value at some point. */

     191                 :            : 
     192                 :            : /**
     193                 :            :  * Data structure for an individual peer. This struct is not protected by
     194                 :            :  * cs_main since it does not contain validation-critical data.
     195                 :            :  *
     196                 :            :  * Memory is owned by shared pointers and this object is destructed when
     197                 :            :  * the refcount drops to zero.
     198                 :            :  *
     199                 :            :  * Mutexes inside this struct must not be held when locking m_peer_mutex.
     200                 :            :  *
     201                 :            :  * TODO: move most members from CNodeState to this structure.
     202                 :            :  * TODO: move remaining application-layer data members from CNode to this structure.

     208                 :            :     /** Services we offered to this peer.
     209                 :            :      *
     210                 :            :      *  This is supplied by CConnman during peer initialization. It's const
     211                 :            :      *  because there is no protocol defined for renegotiating services
     212                 :            :      *  initially offered to a peer. The set of local services we offer should
     213                 :            :      *  not change after initialization.
     214                 :            :      *
     215                 :            :      *  An interesting example of this is NODE_NETWORK and initial block
     216                 :            :      *  download: a node which starts up from scratch doesn't have any blocks
     217                 :            :      *  to serve, but still advertises NODE_NETWORK because it will eventually
     218                 :            :      *  fulfill this role after IBD completes. P2P code is written in such a
     219                 :            :      *  way that it can gracefully handle peers who don't make good on their

     316                 :            :     /** Probabilistic filter to track recent addr messages relayed with this
     317                 :            :      *  peer. Used to avoid relaying redundant addresses to this peer.
     318                 :            :      *
     319                 :            :      *  We initialize this filter for outbound peers (other than
     320                 :            :      *  block-relay-only connections) or when an inbound peer sends us an
     321                 :            :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     322                 :            :      *
     323                 :            :      *  Presence of this filter must correlate with m_addr_relay_enabled.
     324                 :            :      **/
     325                 :            :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_addr_known GUARDED_BY(NetEventsInterface::g_msgproc_mutex);
     326                 :            :     /** Whether we are participating in address relay with this connection.
     327                 :            :      *
     328                 :            :      *  We set this bool to true for outbound peers (other than
     329                 :            :      *  block-relay-only connections), or when an inbound peer sends us an
     330                 :            :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     331                 :            :      *
     332                 :            :      *  We use this bool to decide whether a peer is eligible for gossiping
     333                 :            :      *  addr messages. This avoids relaying to peers that are unlikely to
     334                 :            :      *  forward them, effectively blackholing self announcements. Reasons
     335                 :            :      *  peers might support addr relay on the link include that they connected
     336                 :            :      *  to us as a block-relay-only peer or they are a light client.
     337                 :            :      *
     338                 :            :      *  This field must correlate with whether m_addr_known has been
     339                 :            :      *  initialized.*/
     340                 :       5953 :     std::atomic_bool m_addr_relay_enabled{false};

     404                 :            : 
     405                 :            : using PeerRef = std::shared_ptr<Peer>;
     406                 :            : 
     407                 :            : /**
     408                 :            :  * Maintain validation-specific state about nodes, protected by cs_main, instead
     409                 :            :  * by CNode's own locks. This simplifies asynchronous operation, where
     410                 :            :  * processing of incoming data is done after the ProcessMessage call returns,
     411                 :            :  * and we're no longer holding the node's locks.
     412                 :            :  */
     413                 :            : struct CNodeState {
     414                 :            :     //! The best known block we know this peer has announced.
     415                 :       5953 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestKnownBlock{nullptr};
     416                 :            :     //! The hash of the last unknown block this peer has announced.
     417                 :       5953 :     uint256 hashLastUnknownBlock{};
     418                 :            :     //! The last full block we both have.
     419                 :       5953 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexLastCommonBlock{nullptr};
     420                 :            :     //! The best header we have sent our peer.
     421                 :       5953 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestHeaderSent{nullptr};
     422                 :            :     //! Whether we've started headers synchronization with this peer.
     423                 :       5953 :     bool fSyncStarted{false};
     424                 :            :     //! Since when we're stalling block download progress (in microseconds), or 0.
     425                 :       5953 :     std::chrono::microseconds m_stalling_since{0us};
     426                 :            :     std::list<QueuedBlock> vBlocksInFlight;
     427                 :            :     //! When the first entry in vBlocksInFlight started downloading. Don't care when vBlocksInFlight is empty.
     428         [ +  - ]:       5953 :     std::chrono::microseconds m_downloading_since{0us};
     429                 :            :     //! Whether we consider this a preferred download peer.
     430                 :       5953 :     bool fPreferredDownload{false};
     431                 :            :     /** Whether this peer wants invs or cmpctblocks (when possible) for block announcements. */
     432                 :       5953 :     bool m_requested_hb_cmpctblocks{false};
     433                 :            :     /** Whether this peer will send us cmpctblocks if we request them. */
     434                 :       5953 :     bool m_provides_cmpctblocks{false};
     435                 :            : 
     436                 :            :     /** State used to enforce CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT and EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL logic.
     437                 :            :       *
     438                 :            :       * Both are only in effect for outbound, non-manual, non-protected connections.
     439                 :            :       * Any peer protected (m_protect = true) is not chosen for eviction. A peer is
     440                 :            :       * marked as protected if all of these are true:
     441                 :            :       *   - its connection type is IsBlockOnlyConn() == false
     442                 :            :       *   - it gave us a valid connecting header
     443                 :            :       *   - we haven't reached MAX_OUTBOUND_PEERS_TO_PROTECT_FROM_DISCONNECT yet
     444                 :            :       *   - its chain tip has at least as much work as ours
     445                 :            :       *
     446                 :            :       * CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT: if a peer's best known block has less work than our tip,
     447                 :            :       * set a timeout CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT in the future:
     448                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block now has more work than our tip
     449                 :            :       *     when the timeout was set, then either reset the timeout or clear it
     450                 :            :       *     (after comparing against our current tip's work)
     451                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block still has less work than our
     452                 :            :       *     tip did when the timeout was set, then send a getheaders message,
     453                 :            :       *     and set a shorter timeout, HEADERS_RESPONSE_TIME seconds in future.
     454                 :            :       *     If their best known block is still behind when that new timeout is
     455                 :            :       *     reached, disconnect.
     456                 :            :       *
     457                 :            :       * EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL: after each interval, if we have too many outbound peers,
     458                 :            :       * drop the outbound one that least recently announced us a new block.
     459                 :            :       */
     460                 :       5953 :     struct ChainSyncTimeoutState {
     461                 :            :         //! A timeout used for checking whether our peer has sufficiently synced
     462                 :       5953 :         std::chrono::seconds m_timeout{0s};
     463                 :            :         //! A header with the work we require on our peer's chain
     464                 :       5953 :         const CBlockIndex* m_work_header{nullptr};
     465                 :            :         //! After timeout is reached, set to true after sending getheaders
     466                 :       5953 :         bool m_sent_getheaders{false};
     467                 :            :         //! Whether this peer is protected from disconnection due to a bad/slow chain
     468                 :       5953 :         bool m_protect{false};
     469                 :            :     };
     470                 :            : 
     471                 :            :     ChainSyncTimeoutState m_chain_sync;
     472                 :            : 
     473                 :            :     //! Time of last new block announcement
     474                 :       5953 :     int64_t m_last_block_announcement{0};
     475                 :            : 
     476                 :            :     //! Whether this peer is an inbound connection
     477                 :            :     const bool m_is_inbound;
     478                 :            : 
     479         [ +  - ]:      11906 :     CNodeState(bool is_inbound) : m_is_inbound(is_inbound) {}

     605                 :            :      *                     reconsidered, creating more work, possibly for other peers.

     628                 :            :     arith_uint256 GetAntiDoSWorkThreshold();

     634                 :            :     bool CheckHeadersAreContinuous(const std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers) const;
     635                 :            :     /** Try to continue a low-work headers sync that has already begun.
     636                 :            :      * Assumes the caller has already verified the headers connect, and has
     637                 :            :      * checked that each header satisfies the proof-of-work target included in
     638                 :            :      * the header.
     639                 :            :      *  @param[in]  peer                            The peer we're syncing with.
     640                 :            :      *  @param[in]  pfrom                           CNode of the peer
     641                 :            :      *  @param[in,out] headers                      The headers to be processed.
     642                 :            :      *  @return     True if the passed in headers were successfully processed
     643                 :            :      *              as the continuation of a low-work headers sync in progress;
     644                 :            :      *              false otherwise.
     645                 :            :      *              If false, the passed in headers will be returned back to
     646                 :            :      *              the caller.
     647                 :            :      *              If true, the returned headers may be empty, indicating
     648                 :            :      *              there is no more work for the caller to do; or the headers
     649                 :            :      *              may be populated with entries that have passed anti-DoS
     650                 :            :      *              checks (and therefore may be validated for block index
     651                 :            :      *              acceptance by the caller).
     652                 :            :      */
     653                 :            :     bool IsContinuationOfLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom,

     665                 :            :      *              calling); false otherwise.

     808                 :            : 
     809                 :            :     bool AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid)
     810                 :            :         EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, !m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex);
     811                 :            : 
     812                 :            :     /**
     813                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that were recently rejected by the mempool.
     814                 :            :      * These are not rerequested until the chain tip changes, at which point
     815                 :            :      * the entire filter is reset.
     816                 :            :      *
     817                 :            :      * Without this filter we'd be re-requesting txs from each of our peers,
     818                 :            :      * increasing bandwidth consumption considerably. For instance, with 100
     819                 :            :      * peers, half of which relay a tx we don't accept, that might be a 50x
     820                 :            :      * bandwidth increase. A flooding attacker attempting to roll-over the
     821                 :            :      * filter using minimum-sized, 60byte, transactions might manage to send
     822                 :            :      * 1000/sec if we have fast peers, so we pick 120,000 to give our peers a
     823                 :            :      * two minute window to send invs to us.
     824                 :            :      *
     825                 :            :      * Decreasing the false positive rate is fairly cheap, so we pick one in a
     826                 :            :      * million to make it highly unlikely for users to have issues with this
     827                 :            :      * filter.
     828                 :            :      *
     829                 :            :      * We typically only add wtxids to this filter. For non-segwit
     830                 :            :      * transactions, the txid == wtxid, so this only prevents us from
     831                 :            :      * re-downloading non-segwit transactions when communicating with
     832                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers -- which is important for avoiding malleation
     833                 :            :      * attacks that could otherwise interfere with transaction relay from
     834                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers. For communicating with wtxidrelay peers, having
     835                 :            :      * the reject filter store wtxids is exactly what we want to avoid
     836                 :            :      * redownload of a rejected transaction.
     837                 :            :      *
     838                 :            :      * In cases where we can tell that a segwit transaction will fail
     839                 :            :      * validation no matter the witness, we may add the txid of such
     840                 :            :      * transaction to the filter as well. This can be helpful when
     841                 :            :      * communicating with txid-relay peers or if we were to otherwise fetch a
     842                 :            :      * transaction via txid (eg in our orphan handling).
     843                 :            :      *
     844                 :            :      * Memory used: 1.3 MB
     845                 :            :      */
     846         [ +  - ]:        625 :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_rejects GUARDED_BY(::cs_main){120'000, 0.000'001};
     847                 :            :     uint256 hashRecentRejectsChainTip GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     848                 :            : 
     849                 :            :     /*
     850                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that have been recently confirmed.
     851                 :            :      * We use this to avoid requesting transactions that have already been
     852                 :            :      * confirnmed.
     853                 :            :      *
     854                 :            :      * Blocks don't typically have more than 4000 transactions, so this should
     855                 :            :      * be at least six blocks (~1 hr) worth of transactions that we can store,
     856                 :            :      * inserting both a txid and wtxid for every observed transaction.
     857                 :            :      * If the number of transactions appearing in a block goes up, or if we are
     858                 :            :      * seeing getdata requests more than an hour after initial announcement, we
     859                 :            :      * can increase this number.
     860                 :            :      * The false positive rate of 1/1M should come out to less than 1
     861                 :            :      * transaction per day that would be inadvertently ignored (which is the
     862                 :            :      * same probability that we have in the reject filter).
     863                 :            :      */
     864                 :            :     Mutex m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex;
     865         [ +  - ]:        625 :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_confirmed_transactions GUARDED_BY(m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex){48'000, 0.000'001};
     866                 :            : 
     867                 :            :     /**
     868                 :            :      * For sending `inv`s to inbound peers, we use a single (exponentially
     869                 :            :      * distributed) timer for all peers. If we used a separate timer for each
     870                 :            :      * peer, a spy node could make multiple inbound connections to us to
     871                 :            :      * accurately determine when we received the transaction (and potentially
     872                 :            :      * determine the transaction's origin). */
     873                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds NextInvToInbounds(std::chrono::microseconds now,
     874                 :            :                                                 std::chrono::seconds average_interval);
     875                 :            : 
     876                 :            : 
     877                 :            :     // All of the following cache a recent block, and are protected by m_most_recent_block_mutex
     878                 :            :     Mutex m_most_recent_block_mutex;
     879                 :            :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> m_most_recent_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     880                 :            :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlockHeaderAndShortTxIDs> m_most_recent_compact_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     881                 :            :     uint256 m_most_recent_block_hash GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);

     883                 :            : 
     884                 :            :     // Data about the low-work headers synchronization, aggregated from all peers' HeadersSyncStates.
     885                 :            :     /** Mutex guarding the other m_headers_presync_* variables. */
     886                 :            :     Mutex m_headers_presync_mutex;
     887                 :            :     /** A type to represent statistics about a peer's low-work headers sync.
     888                 :            :      *
     889                 :            :      * - The first field is the total verified amount of work in that synchronization.
     890                 :            :      * - The second is:
     891                 :            :      *   - nullopt: the sync is in REDOWNLOAD phase (phase 2).
     892                 :            :      *   - {height, timestamp}: the sync has the specified tip height and block timestamp (phase 1).
     893                 :            :      */
     894                 :            :     using HeadersPresyncStats = std::pair<arith_uint256, std::optional<std::pair<int64_t, uint32_t>>>;
     895                 :            :     /** Statistics for all peers in low-work headers sync. */
     896                 :        625 :     std::map<NodeId, HeadersPresyncStats> m_headers_presync_stats GUARDED_BY(m_headers_presync_mutex) {};
     897                 :            :     /** The peer with the most-work entry in m_headers_presync_stats. */
     898                 :        625 :     NodeId m_headers_presync_bestpeer GUARDED_BY(m_headers_presync_mutex) {-1};
     899                 :            :     /** The m_headers_presync_stats improved, and needs signalling. */

     935                 :            : 
     936                 :            :     /**
     937                 :            :     * \brief Find next blocks to download from a peer after a starting block.
     938                 :            :     *
     939                 :            :     * \param vBlocks      Vector of blocks to download which will be appended to.
     940                 :            :     * \param peer         Peer which blocks will be downloaded from.
     941                 :            :     * \param state        Pointer to the state of the peer.
     942                 :            :     * \param pindexWalk   Pointer to the starting block to add to vBlocks.
     943                 :            :     * \param count        Maximum number of blocks to allow in vBlocks. No more
     944                 :            :     *                     blocks will be added if it reaches this size.
     945                 :            :     * \param nWindowEnd   Maximum height of blocks to allow in vBlocks. No
     946                 :            :     *                     blocks will be added above this height.

     948                 :            :     *                     provided, any next blocks which are already contained
     949                 :            :     *                     in this chain will not be appended to vBlocks, but
     950                 :            :     *                     instead will be used to update the
     951                 :            :     *                     state->pindexLastCommonBlock pointer.
     952                 :            :     * \param nodeStaller  Optional pointer to a NodeId variable that will receive
     953                 :            :     *                     the ID of another peer that might be causing this peer
     954                 :            :     *                     to stall. This is set to the ID of the peer which
     955                 :            :     *                     first requested the first in-flight block in the
     956                 :            :     *                     download window. It is only set if vBlocks is empty at
     957                 :            :     *                     the end of this function call and if increasing
     958                 :            :     *                     nWindowEnd by 1 would cause it to be non-empty (which
     959                 :            :     *                     indicates the download might be stalled because every
     960                 :            :     *                     block in the window is in flight and no other peer is
     961                 :            :     *                     trying to download the next block).

    1018                 :            : 
    1019                 :            :     /**
    1020                 :            :      * Estimates the distance, in blocks, between the best-known block and the network chain tip.
    1021                 :            :      * Utilizes the best-block time and the chainparams blocks spacing to approximate it.
    1022                 :            :      */
    1023                 :            :     int64_t ApproximateBestBlockDepth() const;
    1024                 :            : 
    1025                 :            :     /**
    1026                 :            :      * To prevent fingerprinting attacks, only send blocks/headers outside of
    1027                 :            :      * the active chain if they are no more than a month older (both in time,
    1028                 :            :      * and in best equivalent proof of work) than the best header chain we know
    1029                 :            :      * about and we fully-validated them at some point.
    1030                 :            :      */

    1395                 :            : 
    1396                 :            : // Logic for calculating which blocks to download from a given peer, given our current tip.

    1767                 :            :     // due to a new block arriving or other large transfer.

    1769                 :            :     // since pingtime does not update until the ping is complete, which might take a while.

    1985                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::StartScheduledTasks(CScheduler& scheduler)
    1986                 :            : {
    1987                 :            :     // Stale tip checking and peer eviction are on two different timers, but we
    1988                 :            :     // don't want them to get out of sync due to drift in the scheduler, so we

    1990                 :            :     // timer.

    2049                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::BlockDisconnected(const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> &block, const CBlockIndex* pindex)
    2050                 :            : {
    2051                 :            :     // To avoid relay problems with transactions that were previously
    2052                 :            :     // confirmed, clear our filter of recently confirmed transactions whenever
    2053                 :            :     // there's a reorg.
    2054                 :            :     // This means that in a 1-block reorg (where 1 block is disconnected and
    2055                 :            :     // then another block reconnected), our filter will drop to having only one
    2056                 :            :     // block's worth of transactions in it, but that should be fine, since
    2057                 :            :     // presumably the most common case of relaying a confirmed transaction
    2058                 :            :     // should be just after a new block containing it is found.
    2059                 :          0 :     LOCK(m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex);
    2060         [ #  # ]:          0 :     m_recent_confirmed_transactions.reset();
    2061                 :          0 : }
    2062                 :            : 
    2063                 :            : /**
    2064                 :            :  * Maintain state about the best-seen block and fast-announce a compact block
    2065                 :            :  * to compatible peers.
    2066                 :            :  */
    2067                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::NewPoWValidBlock(const CBlockIndex *pindex, const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock>& pblock)

    2069                 :          0 :     auto pcmpctblock = std::make_shared<const CBlockHeaderAndShortTxIDs>(*pblock);

    2072                 :            :

    2074                 :          0 :         return;

    2076                 :            :

    2078                 :            :

    2253                 :            : 
    2254                 :        236 : void PeerManagerImpl::RelayAddress(NodeId originator,
    2255                 :            :                                    const CAddress& addr,
    2256                 :            :                                    bool fReachable)
    2257                 :            : {
    2258                 :            :     // We choose the same nodes within a given 24h window (if the list of connected
    2259                 :            :     // nodes does not change) and we don't relay to nodes that already know an
    2260                 :            :     // address. So within 24h we will likely relay a given address once. This is to
    2261                 :            :     // prevent a peer from unjustly giving their address better propagation by sending
    2262                 :            :     // it to us repeatedly.
    2263                 :            : 
    2264   [ -  +  #  # ]:        236 :     if (!fReachable && !addr.IsRelayable()) return;
    2265                 :            : 
    2266                 :            :     // Relay to a limited number of other nodes
    2267                 :            :     // Use deterministic randomness to send to the same nodes for 24 hours
    2268                 :            :     // at a time so the m_addr_knowns of the chosen nodes prevent repeats
    2269                 :        236 :     const uint64_t hash_addr{CServiceHash(0, 0)(addr)};
    2270                 :        236 :     const auto current_time{GetTime<std::chrono::seconds>()};
    2271                 :            :     // Adding address hash makes exact rotation time different per address, while preserving periodicity.
    2272                 :        236 :     const uint64_t time_addr{(static_cast<uint64_t>(count_seconds(current_time)) + hash_addr) / count_seconds(ROTATE_ADDR_RELAY_DEST_INTERVAL)};
    2273                 :        472 :     const CSipHasher hasher{m_connman.GetDeterministicRandomizer(RANDOMIZER_ID_ADDRESS_RELAY)
    2274                 :        236 :                                 .Write(hash_addr)
    2275                 :        236 :                                 .Write(time_addr)};
    2276                 :            : 
    2277                 :            :     // Relay reachable addresses to 2 peers. Unreachable addresses are relayed randomly to 1 or 2 peers.
    2278         [ +  - ]:        236 :     unsigned int nRelayNodes = (fReachable || (hasher.Finalize() & 1)) ? 2 : 1;
    2279                 :            : 
    2280                 :        236 :     std::array<std::pair<uint64_t, Peer*>, 2> best{{{0, nullptr}, {0, nullptr}}};
    2281         [ -  + ]:        236 :     assert(nRelayNodes <= best.size());
    2282                 :            :

    2284                 :            :

    2405                 :            :                 // CMerkleBlock just contains hashes, so also push any transactions in the block the client did not see

    2407                 :            :                 // Note that there is currently no way for a node to request any single transactions we didn't send here -
    2408                 :            :                 // they must either disconnect and retry or request the full block.
    2409                 :            :                 // Thus, the protocol spec specified allows for us to provide duplicate txn here,
    2410                 :            :                 // however we MUST always provide at least what the remote peer needs
    2411                 :            :                 typedef std::pair<unsigned int, uint256> PairType;
    2412         [ +  + ]:       1020 :                 for (PairType& pair : merkleBlock.vMatchedTxn)
    2413   [ +  -  +  -  :        456 :                     MakeAndPushMessage(pfrom, NetMsgType::TX, TX_NO_WITNESS(*pblock->vtx[pair.first]));
                   +  - ]
    2414                 :        564 :             }
    2415                 :            :             // else
    2416                 :            :             // no response
    2417   [ +  -  +  - ]:        755 :         } else if (inv.IsMsgCmpctBlk()) {

    2524                 :            :         // recursively walking the dependencies of relevant unconfirmed
    2525                 :            :         // transactions. SPV clients want to do that because they want to know
    2526                 :            :         // about (and store and rebroadcast and risk analyze) the dependencies
    2527                 :            :         // of transactions relevant to them, without having to download the
    2528                 :            :         // entire memory pool.

    2591                 :            : /**

    2596                 :            :  *

    2727                 :       1271 : bool PeerManagerImpl::TryLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom, const CBlockIndex* chain_start_header, std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)
    2728                 :            : {
    2729                 :            :     // Calculate the claimed total work on this chain.
    2730                 :       1271 :     arith_uint256 total_work = chain_start_header->nChainWork + CalculateClaimedHeadersWork(headers);
    2731                 :            : 
    2732                 :            :     // Our dynamic anti-DoS threshold (minimum work required on a headers chain
    2733                 :            :     // before we'll store it)
    2734                 :       1271 :     arith_uint256 minimum_chain_work = GetAntiDoSWorkThreshold();
    2735                 :            : 
    2736                 :            :     // Avoid DoS via low-difficulty-headers by only processing if the headers
    2737                 :            :     // are part of a chain with sufficient work.
    2738         [ +  + ]:       1271 :     if (total_work < minimum_chain_work) {
    2739                 :            :         // Only try to sync with this peer if their headers message was full;
    2740                 :            :         // otherwise they don't have more headers after this so no point in
    2741                 :            :         // trying to sync their too-little-work chain.
    2742         [ -  + ]:         19 :         if (headers.size() == MAX_HEADERS_RESULTS) {
    2743                 :            :             // Note: we could advance to the last header in this set that is
    2744                 :            :             // known to us, rather than starting at the first header (which we
    2745                 :            :             // may already have); however this is unlikely to matter much since
    2746                 :            :             // ProcessHeadersMessage() already handles the case where all
    2747                 :            :             // headers in a received message are already known and are
    2748                 :            :             // ancestors of m_best_header or chainActive.Tip(), by skipping
    2749                 :            :             // this logic in that case. So even if the first header in this set

    3085                 :       1908 :         return;
    3086         [ -  + ]:        572 :     } else if (state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_WITNESS_STRIPPED) {
    3087                 :            :         // We can add the wtxid of this transaction to our reject filter.
    3088                 :            :         // Do not add txids of witness transactions or witness-stripped
    3089                 :            :         // transactions to the filter, as they can have been malleated;
    3090                 :            :         // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    3091                 :            :         // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that
    3092                 :            :         // do not support wtxid-based relay. See
    3093                 :            :         // https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8279 for details.
    3094                 :            :         // We can remove this restriction (and always add wtxids to
    3095                 :            :         // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once
    3096                 :            :         // wtxid-based relay is broadly deployed.
    3097                 :            :         // See also comments in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18044#discussion_r443419034
    3098                 :            :         // for concerns around weakening security of unupgraded nodes
    3099                 :            :         // if we start doing this too early.
    3100                 :        572 :         m_recent_rejects.insert(ptx->GetWitnessHash().ToUint256());
    3101                 :        572 :         m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(ptx->GetWitnessHash());
    3102                 :            :         // If the transaction failed for TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD,
    3103                 :            :         // then we know that the witness was irrelevant to the policy
    3104                 :            :         // failure, since this check depends only on the txid
    3105                 :            :         // (the scriptPubKey being spent is covered by the txid).
    3106                 :            :         // Add the txid to the reject filter to prevent repeated
    3107                 :            :         // processing of this transaction in the event that child
    3108                 :            :         // transactions are later received (resulting in
    3109                 :            :         // parent-fetching by txid via the orphan-handling logic).
    3110   [ +  +  +  - ]:        572 :         if (state.GetResult() == TxValidationResult::TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD && ptx->HasWitness()) {
    3111                 :          0 :             m_recent_rejects.insert(ptx->GetHash().ToUint256());
    3112                 :          0 :             m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(ptx->GetHash());
    3113                 :          0 :         }
    3114   [ +  -  +  + ]:        572 :         if (maybe_add_extra_compact_tx && RecursiveDynamicUsage(*ptx) < 100000) {
    3115                 :        566 :             AddToCompactExtraTransactions(ptx);
    3116                 :        566 :         }
    3117                 :        572 :     }
    3118                 :            : 
    3119                 :        572 :     MaybePunishNodeForTx(nodeid, state);
    3120                 :            :

    3422                 :            :             // Note that CheckBlock can only fail for one of a few reasons:
    3423                 :            :             // 1. bad-proof-of-work (impossible here, because we've already
    3424                 :            :             //    accepted the header)
    3425                 :            :             // 2. merkleroot doesn't match the transactions given (already
    3426                 :            :             //    caught in FillBlock with READ_STATUS_FAILED, so
    3427                 :            :             //    impossible here)
    3428                 :            :             // 3. the block is otherwise invalid (eg invalid coinbase,
    3429                 :            :             //    block is too big, too many legacy sigops, etc).
    3430                 :            :             // So if CheckBlock failed, #3 is the only possibility.
    3431                 :            :             // Under BIP 152, we don't discourage the peer unless proof of work is
    3432                 :            :             // invalid (we don't require all the stateless checks to have
    3433                 :            :             // been run).  This is handled below, so just treat this as
    3434                 :            :             // though the block was successfully read, and rely on the
    3435                 :            :             // handling in ProcessNewBlock to ensure the block index is
    3436                 :            :             // updated, etc.
    3437         [ #  # ]:          0 :             RemoveBlockRequest(block_transactions.blockhash, pfrom.GetId()); // it is now an empty pointer
    3438                 :          0 :             fBlockRead = true;
    3439                 :            :             // mapBlockSource is used for potentially punishing peers and
    3440                 :            :             // updating which peers send us compact blocks, so the race
    3441                 :            :             // between here and cs_main in ProcessNewBlock is fine.
    3442                 :            :             // BIP 152 permits peers to relay compact blocks after validating
    3443                 :            :             // the header only; we should not punish peers if the block turns
    3444                 :            :             // out to be invalid.
    3445   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             mapBlockSource.emplace(block_transactions.blockhash, std::make_pair(pfrom.GetId(), false));
    3446                 :            :         }
    3447         [ +  - ]:         89 :     } // Don't hold cs_main when we call into ProcessNewBlock
    3448         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (fBlockRead) {
    3449                 :            :         // Since we requested this block (it was in mapBlocksInFlight), force it to be processed,
    3450                 :            :         // even if it would not be a candidate for new tip (missing previous block, chain not long enough, etc)
    3451                 :            :         // This bypasses some anti-DoS logic in AcceptBlock (eg to prevent
    3452                 :            :         // disk-space attacks), but this should be safe due to the
    3453                 :            :         // protections in the compact block handler -- see related comment
    3454                 :            :         // in compact block optimistic reconstruction handling.
    3455         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ProcessBlock(pfrom, pblock, /*force_processing=*/true, /*min_pow_checked=*/true);
    3456                 :          0 :     }
    3457                 :          0 :     return;
    3458                 :         89 : }

    4028         [ +  + ]:       1645 :         if (best_block != nullptr) {
    4029                 :            :             // If we haven't started initial headers-sync with this peer, then
    4030                 :            :             // consider sending a getheaders now. On initial startup, there's a
    4031                 :            :             // reliability vs bandwidth tradeoff, where we are only trying to do
    4032                 :            :             // initial headers sync with one peer at a time, with a long
    4033                 :            :             // timeout (at which point, if the sync hasn't completed, we will
    4034                 :            :             // disconnect the peer and then choose another). In the meantime,
    4035                 :            :             // as new blocks are found, we are willing to add one new peer per
    4036                 :            :             // block to sync with as well, to sync quicker in the case where
    4037                 :            :             // our initial peer is unresponsive (but less bandwidth than we'd
    4038                 :            :             // use if we turned on sync with all peers).

    4308                 :            : 
    4309                 :            :         // We do the AlreadyHaveTx() check using wtxid, rather than txid - in the
    4310                 :            :         // absence of witness malleation, this is strictly better, because the
    4311                 :            :         // recent rejects filter may contain the wtxid but rarely contains
    4312                 :            :         // the txid of a segwit transaction that has been rejected.
    4313                 :            :         // In the presence of witness malleation, it's possible that by only
    4314                 :            :         // doing the check with wtxid, we could overlook a transaction which
    4315                 :            :         // was confirmed with a different witness, or exists in our mempool
    4316                 :            :         // with a different witness, but this has limited downside:
    4317                 :            :         // mempool validation does its own lookup of whether we have the txid
    4318                 :            :         // already; and an adversary can already relay us old transactions
    4319                 :            :         // (older than our recency filter) if trying to DoS us, without any need
    4320                 :            :         // for witness malleation.

    4325                 :            :                 // the node to function as a gateway for nodes hidden behind it.

    4333                 :            :                 }
    4334                 :         46 :             }
    4335                 :            :             // If a tx is detected by m_recent_rejects it is ignored. Because we haven't
    4336                 :            :             // submitted the tx to our mempool, we won't have computed a DoS
    4337                 :            :             // score for it or determined exactly why we consider it invalid.
    4338                 :            :             //
    4339                 :            :             // This means we won't penalize any peer subsequently relaying a DoSy
    4340                 :            :             // tx (even if we penalized the first peer who gave it to us) because
    4341                 :            :             // we have to account for m_recent_rejects showing false positives. In
    4342                 :            :             // other words, we shouldn't penalize a peer if we aren't *sure* they
    4343                 :            :             // submitted a DoSy tx.
    4344                 :            :             //
    4345                 :            :             // Note that m_recent_rejects doesn't just record DoSy or invalid

    4654                 :            :             // (eg disk space). Because we only try to reconstruct blocks when
    4655                 :            :             // we're close to caught up (via the CanDirectFetch() requirement
    4656                 :            :             // above, combined with the behavior of not requesting blocks until
    4657                 :            :             // we have a chain with at least the minimum chain work), and we ignore

    4845         [ +  + ]:       4379 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PING) {
    4846         [ +  + ]:        185 :         if (pfrom.GetCommonVersion() > BIP0031_VERSION) {
    4847                 :        145 :             uint64_t nonce = 0;
    4848         [ +  + ]:        145 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    4849                 :            :             // Echo the message back with the nonce. This allows for two useful features:
    4850                 :            :             //
    4851                 :            :             // 1) A remote node can quickly check if the connection is operational
    4852                 :            :             // 2) Remote nodes can measure the latency of the network thread. If this node
    4853                 :            :             //    is overloaded it won't respond to pings quickly and the remote node can
    4854                 :            :             //    avoid sending us more work, like chain download requests.
    4855                 :            :             //
    4856                 :            :             // The nonce stops the remote getting confused between different pings: without
    4857                 :            :             // it, if the remote node sends a ping once per second and this node takes 5
    4858                 :            :             // seconds to respond to each, the 5th ping the remote sends would appear to
    4859                 :            :             // return very quickly.
    4860   [ +  -  +  - ]:        124 :             MakeAndPushMessage(pfrom, NetMsgType::PONG, nonce);
    4861                 :        145 :         }
    4862                 :        164 :         return;
    4863                 :            :     }
    4864                 :            :

    5211                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::EvictExtraOutboundPeers(std::chrono::seconds now)
    5212                 :            : {
    5213                 :            :     // If we have any extra block-relay-only peers, disconnect the youngest unless
    5214                 :            :     // it's given us a block -- in which case, compare with the second-youngest, and
    5215                 :            :     // out of those two, disconnect the peer who least recently gave us a block.
    5216                 :            :     // The youngest block-relay-only peer would be the extra peer we connected
    5217                 :            :     // to temporarily in order to sync our tip; see net.cpp.
    5218                 :            :     // Note that we use higher nodeid as a measure for most recent connection.

    5936                 :            :         // (with N the number of peers from which we're downloading validated blocks), disconnect due to timeout.
    5937                 :            :         // We compensate for other peers to prevent killing off peers due to our own downstream link
